question: #21 if you’re still doing the prompts??  😁
answer:
Here you go! Thank you for this! xx. - MJ


Peter was staring down the barrel of a gun.

That’s when it dawned on him, oh, oh yeah, I am neck deep in shit.

See, no matter which way he swung this, he’d still get his ass handed to him on a silver platter. If not by this gunman then by Aunt May or Tony; whichever one got to him first. It was hours passed his curfew but he was awakened by the police scanner beside his bed, reporting a jewelry store heist happening only a few blocks over. Queens was sizable city and a robbery was happening only a few blocks from where he lived. How could he not go? Aunt May couldn’t possibly get mad at him for doing his job. It was only 2 AM and he’d only be around the corner. Come on, that was pure Spider-Man luck.

It turned out the sensation he thought was luck was apparently indigestion from Aunt May’s meatloaf because so far nothing was going his way. Two armed thieves had been webbed up but the third had ran leaving him alone with one.

“I’m bulletproof,” Peter began, throwing his hands in the air. “But please, don’t shoot me.” The suit was bulletproof, sure, but that didn’t mean getting shot wouldn’t still hurt like hell. There was still flesh under all that nanotechnology. How would he explain bullet indentations to Mr. Stark?

The gunman smiled behind the ski mask, trailing the gun from his head and to his chest.

“I will kill you.” He cocked the gun. “And history can decide whether I am the hero or the villain.”

Peter shuddered. That sounded like something out of a James Bond movie. It would be kind of cool, if, y’know, he didn’t have a gun aimed at his chest.

“Yeahyeahyeah, cool, cool, cool. I hear you, I do. But listen, I just had this suit dry cleaned and it would be a shame if you scuffed it with your bullets. So can we skip all the shooty-shooty stuff and jump to where I arrest you and then disappear into the sunrise?” Peter slowly began tip backwards out of the door frame where the glass had been shattered. Faintly, in the distance, he could hear sirens nearing and behind him repulsors cut out and metal crunched the concrete behind him. Oh no. Papa Bear Stark was on the scene.

Suddenly, the gun was no longer trained on him but on the figure behind him. Immediately, bullets began to rain around him; the cacophonous ping! of metal bouncing off of metal filling the sleeping city.

“Get behind me, Peter!” Wait…that was…Peter spared a glance over his shoulder. “Uncle Colonel Rhodes?” Peter immediately dove behind the commander. “What are you doing here, sir?”

“Saving your ass, kid, Outta my way.” War Machine stepped around Peter. Within seconds, the gunman was unarmed, cuffed and being guided to the police car out front. Hey, he could’ve done that!

The fly back to Tower was mostly silence, aside from Peter’s occasional protests that he wasn’t injured and he preferred to sneak back into his apartment and go to bed before school tomorrow.

“Nope, Tony requested that he see you personally.” Any other day, Peter would’ve burst open like a pinata of joy under any other circumstance but he just felt throat constrict with panic. They landed outside on the launching pad, starting for the sliding doors.

“But I had it under control, Mr. Rhodes, sir! I mean, you saw! The dude with the gun was all like ‘I’ll make you pay, blargh!’ and I was like ‘Stop! I’m Spider-Man!’ And then, then you came in! You were like ‘I’ve come to steal your thunder, Parker.’ Then the gun dude started shooting, all like bratatata! Pshhew! Vvvvrr--” Rhodey clapped a hand on Peter’s shoulder.

“Yeah Peter, I was there.” Rhodey disengaged the suit and tugged off Peter’s mask. “I know what happened.”

“It sounds like it was a blast!” Peter whirled to his left where Tony was leaning against the door frame, clapping slowly. “Real bang-up job, kid.” Tony sauntered forwards, clapping a hand on James’ shoulders. “Thanks, Rhodey. I got it from here.”

Colonel nodded and cast a bleak glance at Peter before walking inside.

“Mr. Stark! I was fine and I had everything under control–”

“Pipe down, Minnie Mouse. I don’t want to hear it.”

“But Mr. St–”

“Can it, Squirt!” Peter blinked. It was rare that Tony ever raised his voice but it got the job done. Shocked and wide eyed, Peter stood at attention. “Riddle me this, Superman. How does a superhero protect his country, his state– his neighborhood, if he’s dead?”

Peter swallowed audibly. It was a rhetorical but Tony seemed to be waiting for an answer. “He can’t.”

“That’s right. He can’t. You can’t be a friendly neighborhood Spider-Man if you let someone use you as target practice.” Tony ran a hand over his face. “Peter, the 5-0 handle things like this. Theft, vandalism, murder. That’s stuff for the civilians. You need to learn to gauge the urgency of a situation. Walk little old ladies across the street, and save kittens from trees. But don’t walk into gunfire! You have to stop putting your life on the line unnecessarily! You need to stop putting your life on the line, period!”

“Well, where were you, Mr. Stark?” Peter’s voice rose out of him without much thought. “Huh? Where were you then?”

“At home! Just like you should’ve been. I was home with one of my children, praying that my other one made it back safely! Oh, and trying to calm your aunt, who you scared the shit out of, mind you.” Tony jabbed a thumb over his shoulder and Peter looked inside. In the doorway, stood Aunt May in her pajamas, holding his police radio. Oh shit. “So next time you think it’ll be fun to go dance the tango with an armed criminal, please, give someone a warning first.”

The silence hung thickly between the two of them. Peter broke first, hanging his head.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know you are, but go tell that to your aunt.” Tony tugged Peter into a hug. “I’m glad you’re home.”

Peter let out a breath he didn’t know he was holding.

“I’ll go talk to May.”

“You’re gonna be grounded until you’re 30, I can tell you that.” Tony snickered.

Peter winced. Yeah, he had seen that coming.

“Oh goodie.”

summary:
Everyone thought he was joking.
What, you expect people to drop everything they’re doing after telling them something you’ve...
body:
Everyone thought he was joking.


What, you expect people to drop everything they’re doing after telling them something you’ve made jokes about for ages?

It started as soon as they met.


Johnny came waltzing through the door, capri sun in hand, and loudly declared “Ah, there he is. My husband.” as soon as he saw Peter, capri sun in hand.

They divorced three minutes and 29 seconds later, though, after they’ve had a short, but harsh fight about flavours and how ‘the original is NOT better than the fairy one, the hell, Storm?’


It didn’t get better afterwards.

No, they actually became friends. They shared the same sense of humour, no less, and they gradually drove everyone insane with it.


A month into their friendship, they found a ladybug and decided they were gonna raise it together. The divorce happened after they couldn’t agree on a name and asked Fury for his opinion.

The problem of who the single dad was gonna be got resolved by the bug in question himself, who promptly flew away after Peter told him he wouldn’t be able to pay his tuition.

A very sad moment, Tony must admit. Tears were shed.


Three months in, he got a call from Sue, asking for help.

“They wanted to bake, Tony. There’s dough on the ceiling!”


Four months in, he decided they were the soul reason for his hair greying.

‘Go to bed, Peter. You got school tomorrow, Peter.’

Begging and pleading, to no avail. Instead of doing what he was told, the kid kept him awake with constant laughter.

Why he didn’t take his phone away? Simple. Johnny threatened to personally come over to the tower and plan their ‘honeymoon’ in person.

Getting Peter out of bed in the morning was worse than the nightmares he would’ve had if he had slept.


Six months in, the entire team was there to watch their dramatic breakup go down.

What had caused it, Tony couldn’t say if he tried. All he was able to understand between fake crying and Shakespeare-style speeches was something about betrayal, cheating and having to spend christmas alone now.

Peter had probably hung out with that Osborn kid again. Honestly, he fully supported Johnny’s decision on ending the ‘relationship’.


They calmed down again, after that. They were less eccentric. Less talk about their future wedding, the kids that would be left with the divorce, cheating on a friday night.

They were silent, almost. They shared pizza during movies, softly chucked at things on the internet and spent more time out patrolling together.


Tony almost thought they turned into normal kids.

Until Peter told the team during dinner.


“I’m dating Johnny,” he said, immediately quieting every conversation that has been held.

“We know, Pete. You’ve told us a billion times.”


He regretted that sentence as soon as he saw the kid’s face, struck by realization.

Peter looked down, breathing deeply.


“Yeah, but it’s not a joke this time.”


Stares. Stares everywhere.

At him, at Peter, at everyone in near vicinity. But Peter couldn’t see, eyes fixed on the plate in front of him.


He couldn’t bear the silence.


“How long?” Natasha asked, finally.

Had it been silent for only a second longer, Tony probably would have started to cry.


So Peter had a boyfriend, huh? An actual boyfriend.

Johnny Storm, nonetheless. Even though he trusted Peter, knew he wouldn’t do anything irrational (as long as it wouldn’t be too dangerous), he also knew of Storm’s reputation.

If he hurt the kid, in just the slightest of ways, he’d gladly test out every way a fireproof person could be hurt the same.


Not that he was about to injure a child, of course.


“Two months? Two and a half, maybe. It’s not.. It’s new, I guess.”


He still hasn’t looked anyone in the eye.


“He make you happy?”


Yes. Thank you, Rogers. Why hasn’t he thought of that question?


“Very.”


He spotted a smile on Peter’s face; shy, but honest. Perhaps he really wouldn’t have to injure a child.


“That’s good,” Tony eventually spoke up. “I’m happy for you, Pete. We all are.”

“Thank y-,“ Peter attempted to say, but was quickly interrupted again.


“Even though this means the door’s gonna say open when he’s over, of course. I’m not about to take any risks.”


Apparently, that was all he needed to say to make the kid look up.

A smile would have suited him better than the glaring daggers, but sacrifices had to be made.


After all, an angry May was not someone he wanted to be dealing with. Precautions had to be made.

title: Smell of independence (MCU story)
body:
Endgame spoilers, blah blah.

On AO3

Colonel Rhodes took it upon himself to somehow fill in Mr Stark’s position as a mentor for Peter.

It wasn’t going very well.

Not. At. All.

He had been the first guest to arrive on their first morning in the lakeside house, his leg braces whining slightly as he walked up from his car.

“The kid in?” Peter heard through the window of the workshop, as he tried to match the description from a design notebook to an object on the shelf, left there mid-work by Mr Stark, probably days - maybe hours - before he had worked out how to properly use that time-travel-dimension-skipping-thing.

“There’s always a piece of unfinished work left,” he said softly, trying to recall from where the quote might have come. “But then, I suppose, I will be the one to finish these particular pieces.”

“Don’t call him that,” Pepper’s voice travelled the distance between the main house and the shed. “He does have a name, you know.”

“Tony always called him ‘kid’. I’d have to focus to remember, what was it, Patrick…?”

“Peter,” she corrected. “And you’d better remember this, because he is definitely not going away, no matter what various people had suggested recently.”

The man sighed so heavily Peter grimaced.

Here it comes, the 'adult male wisdom’.

He caught himself identifying things that he had heard Aunt May complain about forever. From being patronised, to being constantly corrected to having things explained to him by people who knew less about it than he did.

Because he was a kid.

Because being a kid put him in the same category as women. He would one day grow out of that category and become an adult male, which was apparently the only way one could stop being patronised, corrected and told stuff.

MJ, however, had no such option. And neither had Pepper or Aunt May - they were already quite grown up and that didn’t deter people from talking to them 'slowly and kindly’, which was usually prefaced with a suffering sigh or other adequate sounds.

If that was a part of being an adult, he wanted nothing to do with it.

MJ hated being patronised.

He wondered whether there was some kind of general amnesia thing that men suffered from when they graduated or if it was more of a kind of a society-wide hazing - with the oppressed ones getting promoted to the ruling group and finally getting their turn.

“Pepper—” uh-oh, the suggestive pause of wisdom. “What the hell are you doing with that kid? He is just some troublemaker from Queens, why would you even—”

“Tony wanted it,” she said simply and Peter felt a wave of warmth wash over him.

“Tony wanted a lot of things, not all of them sensible. If you keep this up, who will the kid grow up to be? What is his future? What are his prospects? He will get used to the quality and then…?”

“Then, I suppose, if I do everything correctly, my husband’s apprentice will become my chief designer.  I can’t lose him, Rhodey. I’m not going to suddenly… just discard him. If for no other reason than that Tony liked him and wanted him around. And with him being the only person bright enough to pick up Tony’s unfinished work…”

He blinked.

Oh.

“Tony had put it in the will,” Pepper continued. “And you know what? I like the boy. I wish we had had more time for him to work with Tony. I see his work - I’m not a designer, Rhodey. I’m a businesswoman. But I recognise good engineering ideas when I see them. Tony would have benefited from having Peter around for these five years.”

Another Tortured Male Sigh.

“Aren’t you projecting, just a tiny bit?”

Oh, geez, even I know that sounded like the worst…

“Look here,” she clicked something metallic. “These are the controls for the Rescue unit. Look at them and tell me I’m projecting, or I’m delusional or that Tony didn’t really want what I’m saying right now.”

“Mommy mode,” the Colonel sounded puzzled.

“Override for Morgan’s capsule. Beacon, homing in and full overrides to steer it in case of danger. And a beacon tracker for Morgan herself.”

“So what? This seems perfectly reasonable…?”

Click, click.

“Mother mode…?”

“Beacon, patching in to external and internal sensors, no overrides unless the life signs drop below certain level.”

The man sighed again.

“You had the kid chipped?”

“Both of them. Peter’s design, in fact. But he wasn’t the one to put this in my suit, Rhodey. It was Tony. He added some routine that would discover what Peter works on based on Tony’s basic layouts and it ties these things together. And yes, Peter knows about them, before you ask. He is the one who wrote all the needed code for the capsule overrides.”

“Does he know about his suit being on this list?”

Peter could easily visualise Pepper’s eyeroll.

“How could he not, since he is rebuilding the next one now - and building the new Rescue unit - and he implements the same routines in each of them anew?”

Of course he knew. And he knew how much it annoyed him when Mr Stark used the override. And he knew…

“The overrides in Tony’s suits are even stronger, up to and including locking or running some functions independently from Peter’s direct orders.”

“That’s… messed up, seriously,” Colonel Rhodes sounded somewhat upset for some reason.

“Well, Iron Man One has override for all the suits Tony made,” Pepper seemed, in turn, somewhat indifferent.

A silent breath or two passed.

“And by Iron Man One, which suit do you mean, exactly?”

Low voice. Very low voice.

Adult male threatening tone.

Before he noticed, he was at the door and taking long steps into the living room.

“That would be any suit being currently worn by Iron Man,” he explained. “It works a bit like Air Force One, I suppose. Whichever suit Mr Stark was wearing, automatically became the top of the hierarchy, with Rescue coming as the second one. Also, I’ll enable these overrides in my suit, Pepper. Just in case.”

“Peter, I don’t need you to…”

“You do. And I don’t mind. Mr Stark used them a few times and I must admit it was plenty annoying, but what if something happens to me and you have to be there for Morgan? You won’t be able to take her everywhere and…”

“Fine, fine,” Colonel Rhodes interrupted him harshly. “Which of the suits has the Iron Man One priority right now?”

He seemed rather intent on the topic and Peter kind of wasn’t surprised.

“Friday, which units currently have override control on Rescue unit?”

“None of them, Peter.”

“There, you have it. Friday says there is no suit with override on Rescue, and since Rescue is the second in the hierarchy - becomes automatically the first, with IM One not present. But Rescue only has limited override and…” he looked up at Pepper. “That’s what it’s going to have.”

“Friday,” the colonel said, when Peter paused. “Which of the inactive units had the potential to override Rescue unit?”

A beat.

Until Peter nodded.

“All of the suits in the Iron Man category have this potential, colonel.”

“What would be needed to activate that functionality?”

Another pause.

Another nod.

“It would require Mr Stark’s presence or a delegated individual of Mr Stark’s choosing to activate.”

Rhodes raised his eyebrows and looked at Pepper questioningly. She shrugged and nodded at Peter, who smiled.

“Oh, God,” the colonel sighed. “One last question then… Who the heck made that highly intelligent decision?”

“Tony,” “Mr Stark,” “The boss” they spoke at the same time.

The big man moaned.

“But that’s only the Iron Man suits,” Pepper said reassuringly. “Right now Peter is using his own, which is not in the same cate…” she trailed off, her eyes widening slightly as the sight of Peter’s wrists. “Category,” she swallowed and coughed. “Sorry. Peter, could you bring me the water? The pollen makes my throat dry out in seconds.”

“Sure,” he smiled and nodded at Rhodes. “Anything for you, sir?”

“Something that will make me forget what I’ve just heard,” the man groaned. “But in the absence of hard liquor, anything cold will be fine. Thank you, Parker.”

“Call me Peter, sir. Parker is what my teachers call me and this is supposed to be a vacation…”

The moment he crossed the doorway, Rhodes turned towards Pepper and started whispering furiously. Peter sighed and tried not to listen, but, as usual, all his senses sharpened immediately. Stress always made his hearing much stronger, after all.

And he froze.

“…formalised!”

“He couldn’t. I mean, seriously, Rhodey, what would you have done?”

“I don’t know. Not like I am Tony Stark, am I?”

Pepper sighed.

“I know what he… what he…” she swallowed, he could hear it, even from across the building. “I’m not sure if there is a procedure for this.”

“Adopting someone? There is a whole department of Child Protective Services for this, Pepper, don’t be obtuse.”

“But there was no procedure for adopting a non-existent seventeen-year-old…!”

A miniature supernova went off in Peter’s brain.

“It would have worked before the Decimation - he was at school and Tony was alive and… and now he is too old for this,” he heard Pepper say. “And it wasn’t even about that, really. I mean, Tony did write a will that puts Peter as the main beneficiary - well, after Morgan and me, but a big chunk of mine is shared with Peter, for management purposes.”

“Dear God, did he mean to sign off everything to that kid…!?”

“Have you never seen them together?” Pepper countered softly. “I wish I had had this kind of relationship with my own parents…! And no, definitely not everything, since the company is mine. Peter has a large chunk of shares which mainly wait until he turns twenty-five, as per Tony’s directions.”

“And I’m not sure I won’t be signing the control over to Pepper at the very second I get it,” he added. “I am completely serious. Code? Nanites? AI? I can work with that. Finances and arguing with the stakeholders… not that much. And I’m not being coy or cocky,” he sniffed and shrugged. “I’m being realistic. And, well, I’m not angling at Pepper’s job. Not in this universe or any other. And I will do whatever is needed to make sure she keeps it, too.”

“Peter…”

“Enhanced senses then, kid?” the colonel took over the jug of lemonade Peter had carried to the table, leaving Peter with just Pepper’s water bottle, which Peter proceeded to toss towards her, making the soldier flinch, just a bit. Pepper fetched it from the air with the tiniest possible smirk.

“Sir, I can hear everything in the radius of… Maybe a mile. More or less. If I’m in fight mode, it’s more, expands with stress. I can tell you how many people there are now around the property and that one of your accompanying drivers is playing Candy Crush with his sound on. Also, I am now disturbingly sure that bears do in fact shit in the woods, which is not something I was at any point wishing I could confirm. There are seventeen mice and three lizards living in the basement. Sorry, Pepper. There is a nest of crows nearby, and there are several smaller animals I’m not familiar with, living in the growth around the lake. I know what your people are gossipping about - mostly celebrities, I think.”

“Pepper, did you know about this…?”

“Pepper knows, Captain Wilson knows, doctor Banner knows, director Fury knows…” he shrugged.

It seemed that something had come to a stop. The whole visit, it was supposed to be about something, about Rhodey and him and about - somehow - the older man assuming some kind of responsibility for something.

Fuck me if I’m going to make it easy for him. I may not be Iron Man, but I am his bloody apprentice and if there is one thing I will prove to all of them… is that I’m not going to be an easy target.

He looked up at Pepper, who nodded slightly.

OK then. Ladies first.

“What exactly do you want from Peter, Rhodey?” she asked bluntly, putting her bottle away. “Because if you want to somehow impose on him - get him to participate in some military stunt or, even worse, provide materials for something…” she leaned forward, “I will boot you out of this house without remorse.”

“It’s not exactly that,” the colonel prevaricated and Peter saw his host roll her eyes at the claim.

Oh, boy. Here goes my afternoon. I just hope Morgan will be willing to spill some juice on him after dinner. It should make him leave.

Endgame spoilers, blah blah.

On AO3

Colonel Rhodes took it upon himself to somehow fill in Mr Stark’s position as a mentor for Peter.

It wasn’t going very well.

Not. At. All.

[[MORE]]

He had been the first guest to arrive on their first morning in the lakeside house, his leg braces whining slightly as he walked up from his car.

“The kid in?” Peter heard through the window of the workshop, as he tried to match the description from a design notebook to an object on the shelf, left there mid-work by Mr Stark, probably days - maybe hours - before he had worked out how to properly use that time-travel-dimension-skipping-thing.

“There’s always a piece of unfinished work left,” he said softly, trying to recall from where the quote might have come. “But then, I suppose, I will be the one to finish these particular pieces.”

“Don’t call him that,” Pepper’s voice travelled the distance between the main house and the shed. “He does have a name, you know.”

“Tony always called him ‘kid’. I’d have to focus to remember, what was it, Patrick…?”

“Peter,” she corrected. “And you’d better remember this, because he is definitely not going away, no matter what various people had suggested recently.”

The man sighed so heavily Peter grimaced.

Here it comes, the 'adult male wisdom’.

He caught himself identifying things that he had heard Aunt May complain about forever. From being patronised, to being constantly corrected to having things explained to him by people who knew less about it than he did.

Because he was a kid.

Because being a kid put him in the same category as women. He would one day grow out of that category and become an adult male, which was apparently the only way one could stop being patronised, corrected and told stuff.

MJ, however, had no such option. And neither had Pepper or Aunt May - they were already quite grown up and that didn’t deter people from talking to them 'slowly and kindly’, which was usually prefaced with a suffering sigh or other adequate sounds.

If that was a part of being an adult, he wanted nothing to do with it.

MJ hated being patronised.

He wondered whether there was some kind of general amnesia thing that men suffered from when they graduated or if it was more of a kind of a society-wide hazing - with the oppressed ones getting promoted to the ruling group and finally getting their turn.

“Pepper—” uh-oh, the suggestive pause of wisdom. “What the hell are you doing with that kid? He is just some troublemaker from Queens, why would you even—”

“Tony wanted it,” she said simply and Peter felt a wave of warmth wash over him.

“Tony wanted a lot of things, not all of them sensible. If you keep this up, who will the kid grow up to be? What is his future? What are his prospects? He will get used to the quality and then…?”

“Then, I suppose, if I do everything correctly, my husband’s apprentice will become my chief designer.  I can’t lose him, Rhodey. I’m not going to suddenly… just discard him. If for no other reason than that Tony liked him and wanted him around. And with him being the only person bright enough to pick up Tony’s unfinished work…”

He blinked.

Oh.

“Tony had put it in the will,” Pepper continued. “And you know what? I like the boy. I wish we had had more time for him to work with Tony. I see his work - I’m not a designer, Rhodey. I’m a businesswoman. But I recognise good engineering ideas when I see them. Tony would have benefited from having Peter around for these five years.”

Another Tortured Male Sigh.

“Aren’t you projecting, just a tiny bit?”

Oh, geez, even I know that sounded like the worst…

“Look here,” she clicked something metallic. “These are the controls for the Rescue unit. Look at them and tell me I’m projecting, or I’m delusional or that Tony didn’t really want what I’m saying right now.”

“Mommy mode,” the Colonel sounded puzzled.

“Override for Morgan’s capsule. Beacon, homing in and full overrides to steer it in case of danger. And a beacon tracker for Morgan herself.”

“So what? This seems perfectly reasonable…?”

Click, click.

“Mother mode…?”

“Beacon, patching in to external and internal sensors, no overrides unless the life signs drop below certain level.”

The man sighed again.

“You had the kid chipped?”

“Both of them. Peter’s design, in fact. But he wasn’t the one to put this in my suit, Rhodey. It was Tony. He added some routine that would discover what Peter works on based on Tony’s basic layouts and it ties these things together. And yes, Peter knows about them, before you ask. He is the one who wrote all the needed code for the capsule overrides.”

“Does he know about his suit being on this list?”

Peter could easily visualise Pepper’s eyeroll.

“How could he not, since he is rebuilding the next one now - and building the new Rescue unit - and he implements the same routines in each of them anew?”

Of course he knew. And he knew how much it annoyed him when Mr Stark used the override. And he knew…

“The overrides in Tony’s suits are even stronger, up to and including locking or running some functions independently from Peter’s direct orders.”

“That’s… messed up, seriously,” Colonel Rhodes sounded somewhat upset for some reason.

“Well, Iron Man One has override for all the suits Tony made,” Pepper seemed, in turn, somewhat indifferent.

A silent breath or two passed.

“And by Iron Man One, which suit do you mean, exactly?”

Low voice. Very low voice.

Adult male threatening tone.

Before he noticed, he was at the door and taking long steps into the living room.

“That would be any suit being currently worn by Iron Man,” he explained. “It works a bit like Air Force One, I suppose. Whichever suit Mr Stark was wearing, automatically became the top of the hierarchy, with Rescue coming as the second one. Also, I’ll enable these overrides in my suit, Pepper. Just in case.”

“Peter, I don’t need you to…”

“You do. And I don’t mind. Mr Stark used them a few times and I must admit it was plenty annoying, but what if something happens to me and you have to be there for Morgan? You won’t be able to take her everywhere and…”

“Fine, fine,” Colonel Rhodes interrupted him harshly. “Which of the suits has the Iron Man One priority right now?”

He seemed rather intent on the topic and Peter kind of wasn’t surprised.

“Friday, which units currently have override control on Rescue unit?”

“None of them, Peter.”

“There, you have it. Friday says there is no suit with override on Rescue, and since Rescue is the second in the hierarchy - becomes automatically the first, with IM One not present. But Rescue only has limited override and…” he looked up at Pepper. “That’s what it’s going to have.”

“Friday,” the colonel said, when Peter paused. “Which of the inactive units had the potential to override Rescue unit?”

A beat.

Until Peter nodded.

“All of the suits in the Iron Man category have this potential, colonel.”

“What would be needed to activate that functionality?”

Another pause.

Another nod.

“It would require Mr Stark’s presence or a delegated individual of Mr Stark’s choosing to activate.”

Rhodes raised his eyebrows and looked at Pepper questioningly. She shrugged and nodded at Peter, who smiled.

“Oh, God,” the colonel sighed. “One last question then… Who the heck made that highly intelligent decision?”

“Tony,” “Mr Stark,” “The boss” they spoke at the same time.

The big man moaned.

“But that’s only the Iron Man suits,” Pepper said reassuringly. “Right now Peter is using his own, which is not in the same cate…” she trailed off, her eyes widening slightly as the sight of Peter’s wrists. “Category,” she swallowed and coughed. “Sorry. Peter, could you bring me the water? The pollen makes my throat dry out in seconds.”

“Sure,” he smiled and nodded at Rhodes. “Anything for you, sir?”

“Something that will make me forget what I’ve just heard,” the man groaned. “But in the absence of hard liquor, anything cold will be fine. Thank you, Parker.”

“Call me Peter, sir. Parker is what my teachers call me and this is supposed to be a vacation…”

The moment he crossed the doorway, Rhodes turned towards Pepper and started whispering furiously. Peter sighed and tried not to listen, but, as usual, all his senses sharpened immediately. Stress always made his hearing much stronger, after all.

And he froze.

“…formalised!”

“He couldn’t. I mean, seriously, Rhodey, what would you have done?”

“I don’t know. Not like I am Tony Stark, am I?”

Pepper sighed.

“I know what he… what he…” she swallowed, he could hear it, even from across the building. “I’m not sure if there is a procedure for this.”

“Adopting someone? There is a whole department of Child Protective Services for this, Pepper, don’t be obtuse.”

“But there was no procedure for adopting a non-existent seventeen-year-old…!”

A miniature supernova went off in Peter’s brain.

“It would have worked before the Decimation - he was at school and Tony was alive and… and now he is too old for this,” he heard Pepper say. “And it wasn’t even about that, really. I mean, Tony did write a will that puts Peter as the main beneficiary - well, after Morgan and me, but a big chunk of mine is shared with Peter, for management purposes.”

“Dear God, did he mean to sign off everything to that kid…!?”

“Have you never seen them together?” Pepper countered softly. “I wish I had had this kind of relationship with my own parents…! And no, definitely not everything, since the company is mine. Peter has a large chunk of shares which mainly wait until he turns twenty-five, as per Tony’s directions.”

“And I’m not sure I won’t be signing the control over to Pepper at the very second I get it,” he added. “I am completely serious. Code? Nanites? AI? I can work with that. Finances and arguing with the stakeholders… not that much. And I’m not being coy or cocky,” he sniffed and shrugged. “I’m being realistic. And, well, I’m not angling at Pepper’s job. Not in this universe or any other. And I will do whatever is needed to make sure she keeps it, too.”

“Peter…”

“Enhanced senses then, kid?” the colonel took over the jug of lemonade Peter had carried to the table, leaving Peter with just Pepper’s water bottle, which Peter proceeded to toss towards her, making the soldier flinch, just a bit. Pepper fetched it from the air with the tiniest possible smirk.

“Sir, I can hear everything in the radius of… Maybe a mile. More or less. If I’m in fight mode, it’s more, expands with stress. I can tell you how many people there are now around the property and that one of your accompanying drivers is playing Candy Crush with his sound on. Also, I am now disturbingly sure that bears do in fact shit in the woods, which is not something I was at any point wishing I could confirm. There are seventeen mice and three lizards living in the basement. Sorry, Pepper. There is a nest of crows nearby, and there are several smaller animals I’m not familiar with, living in the growth around the lake. I know what your people are gossipping about - mostly celebrities, I think.”

“Pepper, did you know about this…?”

“Pepper knows, Captain Wilson knows, doctor Banner knows, director Fury knows…” he shrugged.

It seemed that something had come to a stop. The whole visit, it was supposed to be about something, about Rhodey and him and about - somehow - the older man assuming some kind of responsibility for something.

Fuck me if I’m going to make it easy for him. I may not be Iron Man, but I am his bloody apprentice and if there is one thing I will prove to all of them… is that I’m not going to be an easy target.

He looked up at Pepper, who nodded slightly.

OK then. Ladies first.

“What exactly do you want from Peter, Rhodey?” she asked bluntly, putting her bottle away. “Because if you want to somehow impose on him - get him to participate in some military stunt or, even worse, provide materials for something…” she leaned forward, “I will boot you out of this house without remorse.”

“It’s not exactly that,” the colonel prevaricated and Peter saw his host roll her eyes at the claim.

Oh, boy. Here goes my afternoon. I just hope Morgan will be willing to spill some juice on him after dinner. It should make him leave.

Oh.

“Tony had put it in the will,” Pepper continued. “And you know what? I like the boy. I wish we had had more time for him to work with Tony. I see his work - I’m not a designer, Rhodey. I’m a businesswoman. But I recognise good engineering ideas when I see them. Tony would have benefited from having Peter around for these five years.”

Another Tortured Male Sigh.

“Aren’t you projecting, just a tiny bit?”

Oh, geez, even I know that sounded like the worst…

“Look here,” she clicked something metallic. “These are the controls for the Rescue unit. Look at them and tell me I’m projecting, or I’m delusional or that Tony didn’t really want what I’m saying right now.”

“Mommy mode,” the Colonel sounded puzzled.

“Override for Morgan’s capsule. Beacon, homing in and full overrides to steer it in case of danger. And a beacon tracker for Morgan herself.”

“So what? This seems perfectly reasonable…?”

Click, click.

“Mother mode…?”

“Beacon, patching in to external and internal sensors, no overrides unless the life signs drop below certain level.”

The man sighed again.

“You had the kid chipped?”

“Both of them. Peter’s design, in fact. But he wasn’t the one to put this in my suit, Rhodey. It was Tony. He added some routine that would discover what Peter works on based on Tony’s basic layouts and it ties these things together. And yes, Peter knows about them, before you ask. He is the one who wrote all the needed code for the capsule overrides.”

“Does he know about his suit being on this list?”

Peter could easily visualise Pepper’s eyeroll.

“How could he not, since he is rebuilding the next one now - and building the new Rescue unit - and he implements the same routines in each of them anew?”

Of course he knew. And he knew how much it annoyed him when Mr Stark used the override. And he knew…

“The overrides in Tony’s suits are even stronger, up to and including locking or running some functions independently from Peter’s direct orders.”

“That’s… messed up, seriously,” Colonel Rhodes sounded somewhat upset for some reason.

“Well, Iron Man One has override for all the suits Tony made,” Pepper seemed, in turn, somewhat indifferent.

A silent breath or two passed.

“And by Iron Man One, which suit do you mean, exactly?”

Low voice. Very low voice.

Adult male threatening tone.

Before he noticed, he was at the door and taking long steps into the living room.

“That would be any suit being currently worn by Iron Man,” he explained. “It works a bit like Air Force One, I suppose. Whichever suit Mr Stark was wearing, automatically became the top of the hierarchy, with Rescue coming as the second one. Also, I’ll enable these overrides in my suit, Pepper. Just in case.”

“Peter, I don’t need you to…”

“You do. And I don’t mind. Mr Stark used them a few times and I must admit it was plenty annoying, but what if something happens to me and you have to be there for Morgan? You won’t be able to take her everywhere and…”

“Fine, fine,” Colonel Rhodes interrupted him harshly. “Which of the suits has the Iron Man One priority right now?”

He seemed rather intent on the topic and Peter kind of wasn’t surprised.

“Friday, which units currently have override control on Rescue unit?”

“None of them, Peter.”

“There, you have it. Friday says there is no suit with override on Rescue, and since Rescue is the second in the hierarchy - becomes automatically the first, with IM One not present. But Rescue only has limited override and…” he looked up at Pepper. “That’s what it’s going to have.”

“Friday,” the colonel said, when Peter paused. “Which of the inactive units had the potential to override Rescue unit?”

A beat.

Until Peter nodded.

“All of the suits in the Iron Man category have this potential, colonel.”

“What would be needed to activate that functionality?”

Another pause.

Another nod.

“It would require Mr Stark’s presence or a delegated individual of Mr Stark’s choosing to activate.”

Rhodes raised his eyebrows and looked at Pepper questioningly. She shrugged and nodded at Peter, who smiled.

“Oh, God,” the colonel sighed. “One last question then… Who the heck made that highly intelligent decision?”

“Tony,” “Mr Stark,” “The boss” they spoke at the same time.

The big man moaned.

“But that’s only the Iron Man suits,” Pepper said reassuringly. “Right now Peter is using his own, which is not in the same cate…” she trailed off, her eyes widening slightly as the sight of Peter’s wrists. “Category,” she swallowed and coughed. “Sorry. Peter, could you bring me the water? The pollen makes my throat dry out in seconds.”

“Sure,” he smiled and nodded at Rhodes. “Anything for you, sir?”

“Something that will make me forget what I’ve just heard,” the man groaned. “But in the absence of hard liquor, anything cold will be fine. Thank you, Parker.”

“Call me Peter, sir. Parker is what my teachers call me and this is supposed to be a vacation…”

The moment he crossed the doorway, Rhodes turned towards Pepper and started whispering furiously. Peter sighed and tried not to listen, but, as usual, all his senses sharpened immediately. Stress always made his hearing much stronger, after all.

And he froze.

“…formalised!”

“He couldn’t. I mean, seriously, Rhodey, what would you have done?”

“I don’t know. Not like I am Tony Stark, am I?”

Pepper sighed.

“I know what he… what he…” she swallowed, he could hear it, even from across the building. “I’m not sure if there is a procedure for this.”

“Adopting someone? There is a whole department of Child Protective Services for this, Pepper, don’t be obtuse.”

“But there was no procedure for adopting a non-existent seventeen-year-old…!”

A miniature supernova went off in Peter’s brain.

“It would have worked before the Decimation - he was at school and Tony was alive and… and now he is too old for this,” he heard Pepper say. “And it wasn’t even about that, really. I mean, Tony did write a will that puts Peter as the main beneficiary - well, after Morgan and me, but a big chunk of mine is shared with Peter, for management purposes.”

“Dear God, did he mean to sign off everything to that kid…!?”

“Have you never seen them together?” Pepper countered softly. “I wish I had had this kind of relationship with my own parents…! And no, definitely not everything, since the company is mine. Peter has a large chunk of shares which mainly wait until he turns twenty-five, as per Tony’s directions.”

“And I’m not sure I won’t be signing the control over to Pepper at the very second I get it,” he added. “I am completely serious. Code? Nanites? AI? I can work with that. Finances and arguing with the stakeholders… not that much. And I’m not being coy or cocky,” he sniffed and shrugged. “I’m being realistic. And, well, I’m not angling at Pepper’s job. Not in this universe or any other. And I will do whatever is needed to make sure she keeps it, too.”

“Peter…”

“Enhanced senses then, kid?” the colonel took over the jug of lemonade Peter had carried to the table, leaving Peter with just Pepper’s water bottle, which Peter proceeded to toss towards her, making the soldier flinch, just a bit. Pepper fetched it from the air with the tiniest possible smirk.

“Sir, I can hear everything in the radius of… Maybe a mile. More or less. If I’m in fight mode, it’s more, expands with stress. I can tell you how many people there are now around the property and that one of your accompanying drivers is playing Candy Crush with his sound on. Also, I am now disturbingly sure that bears do in fact shit in the woods, which is not something I was at any point wishing I could confirm. There are seventeen mice and three lizards living in the basement. Sorry, Pepper. There is a nest of crows nearby, and there are several smaller animals I’m not familiar with, living in the growth around the lake. I know what your people are gossipping about - mostly celebrities, I think.”

“Pepper, did you know about this…?”

“Pepper knows, Captain Wilson knows, doctor Banner knows, director Fury knows…” he shrugged.

It seemed that something had come to a stop. The whole visit, it was supposed to be about something, about Rhodey and him and about - somehow - the older man assuming some kind of responsibility for something.

Fuck me if I’m going to make it easy for him. I may not be Iron Man, but I am his bloody apprentice and if there is one thing I will prove to all of them… is that I’m not going to be an easy target.

He looked up at Pepper, who nodded slightly.

OK then. Ladies first.

“What exactly do you want from Peter, Rhodey?” she asked bluntly, putting her bottle away. “Because if you want to somehow impose on him - get him to participate in some military stunt or, even worse, provide materials for something…” she leaned forward, “I will boot you out of this house without remorse.”

“It’s not exactly that,” the colonel prevaricated and Peter saw his host roll her eyes at the claim.

Oh, boy. Here goes my afternoon. I just hope Morgan will be willing to spill some juice on him after dinner. It should make him leave.

@bad-poetry-rants-and-fandoms @hpswl-cumbercookie @all-the-fangeekiness @jessieblackwood

Colonel Rhodes took it upon himself to somehow fill in Mr Stark’s position as a mentor for Peter.

It wasn’t going very well.

Not. At. All.

summary: i know spideytorch is mostly just fluff and cute and feelgood when you’re talking about them as teenagers, but think about what...
body:
i know spideytorch is mostly just fluff and cute and feelgood when you’re talking about them as teenagers, but think about what it’s really like.

the late nights they spend together, perched up against fire exits of random apartments, when neither of them can sleep, being forced to stay awake by their terrible thoughts, their regrets, their fears; they can’t always save everyone. they lost people, they saw them die and they can’t find anyone else to blame but themselves.

the calls they have after a nightmare caused one of them to wake up screaming. he saw the building crumbling under the pressure, the bridge breaking down, the pain of being injured. he heard the screams again, the cries of a family member that just realized they’ve lost their brother, their daughter, their mother, their friend and looking around, they screamed once more - after their eyes locked onto the hero, the saviour who didn’t save their loved one.

the long, heartfelt hugs they share after eventually breaking down, when the pain and the sorrow gets too much for their hearts to endure, when they need anything, anyone to make them feel as if they’re enough, as if they’re not the disappointment they see themselves as.

the hunts they have after each other, after a fight gone particularly bad. after one of them ran away from the mess, the panic filling their head bigger than the responsibility they were taught.

the searches when they haven’t heard from each other after a fight, when they don’t know where their friend is, wether he’s okay or injured, maybe dead. the fear of having lost the other too immense to think clearly.

the talks when they meet up, the reassurance they so desperately crave coming from the only person they think can understand. hearing that they’re enough, they’re trying and that’s all that can be asked of them.

the tears running down their cheeks when no one is there to see, to judge. the relief of letting out what has been bottled up for so long.

the feeling of overreacting, of being weak; of not being able to get the help they need from their mentors, their family - their colleagues, in a way, because they’re so much older, so much wiser and they deal with it so much better. they don’t make the mistakes they do. they know how to do their job. they’re not as broken as them.

the pressure and heartbreak doesn’t reach them once they’re adults. it’s running through their blood like gasoline, waiting to blow up as soon as the fire in their hearts gets too close. it accompanies them whereever they go. it never leaves them alone.

and all they want, all they need is someone to help them back up and show them the way. teach them how to save themselves before they save anyone else.

but no one ever does. because no one knows.

they never show.
